ce:caption.ce:simple-para: SDS–PAGE of porcine intestinal acylpeptide hydrolase. The electrophoresis was performed with a 10% polyacrylamide gel, in the absence (A) and presence (B) of SDS. The gel was stained with Coomassie brilliant blue. The following molecular mass markers were used: phosphorylase B (94 000), bovine serum albumin (67 000), ovabulmin (43 000), carbonic anhydrase (30 000), trypsin inhibitor (20 100) and α-lactalbumin (14 400).

Nucleotide sequence and predicted amino acid sequence of APH from porcine intestine. The translated polypeptide chain starts at position +1 and terminates at position +731. The polyadenylation signal (AATAAA) is underlined. The amino acid A104 and the nucleotide 311 are different from the porcine liver APH. The two groups of nucleotides underlined by arrows correspond to S1 and S2 primers.
Purification of acylpeptide hydrolase from pig intestinal mucosa
Amino acid composition of a subunit of purified acylpeptide hydrolase from pig intestinal mucosa

row.entry: The data for both the rat and pig liver enzymes were derived from the amino acid sequences deduced from the nucleotide sequences of the corresponding cDNAs [23,24]. Three different enzymatic preparations were used for pig intestine, and cysteinyl residues were determined as S-carboxymethylcysteine.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Kinetic parameters of the hydrolysis of N-acetylalanyl substrates by acylpeptide hydrolase

row.entry: The enzyme reaction was carried out at 37°C in a 50 mM phosphate buffer at pH 8, as described in Section 2.
Pig intestinal APH was incubated at 37°C for 5 min with each reagent, and the remaining enzyme activity was determined under standard assay conditions using AANA as the substrate.

head.ce:title: Cloning, sequencing and further characterization of acylpeptide hydrolase from porcine intestinal mucosa

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Laboratoire de Biochimie et Biologie de la Nutrition, CNRS-ESA 6033, Faculté des Sciences et Techniques de St-Jérôme, 13397 Marseille Cédex 20, France

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Acylpeptide hydrolase was purified to homogeneity from porcine intestinal mucosa using a seven-step procedure including ammonium sulfate precipitation, gel filtration as well as anion exchange and affinity chromatography. The specific activity of the enzyme reached 105 000 nmol/mg protein per min and the purification was as high as 5500-fold. This tetrameric enzyme is composed of four apparently identical subunits, the molecular mass of which was estimated to be 75 kDa, based on the results of amino acid analysis and gel electrophoresis performed under denaturing conditions. It is likely that the NH2-terminal residue may be acetylated, while serine was found to be the COOH-terminal residue. The hydrolytic activity of the enzyme toward N-acetyl-l-alanine p-nitroanilide at the optimum pH value was increased twofold in the presence of the chloride anion. The Km value calculated from the kinetics of the hydrolysis of acetylalanyl peptides was found to be 0.7±0.1 mM, whereas the Vmax value decreased from 200 to 50 nmol/min per μg of enzyme, depending on the peptidic chain lengths. The Vmax value of the synthetic substrate (250 nmol/min per μg of enzyme) was 25–500% higher than those of the acetylalanyl peptides, depending on the peptide chain length, although the enzyme affinity was slightly lower (1.8 mM as compared with 0.7 mM). In line with data on other animal species and on various tissues, the enzyme seemed likely to be a serine protease, since it was readily inhibited by diisopropyl fluorophosphate and diethyl pyrocarbonate. A 2377-nucleotide long cDNA coding for the enzyme was isolated from pig small intestine. The deduced amino acid sequence consisted of 731 residues and showed a single different amino acid with that of the porcine liver APH, except the N-terminal amino acid which is still probably lacking.

ce:section.ce:para: The NH2-terminal acetylation of intracellular proteins, which takes place in various eukaryotic cells [1,2], raises questions about the removal of N-acetylated residues during the catabolism of intracellular acetylated proteins, as well as that of the acetyl group itself, since free amino acids are necessary to the protein synthesis process. This modification is usually a cotranslational event that occurs when the nascent polypeptide chain is between 20 and 50 residues long [3], but may also occur during the posttranslational steps of protein biosynthesis. Nα-Acetyltransferase, the major enzyme involved in the acetylation of a variety of NH2-terminal residues, catalyzes the transfer of an acetyl group from acetyl coenzyme A to the α-NH2 group of proteins and peptides [4]. Although the biological role of Nα-acetylation has not yet been elucidated, it has been suggested that it may be a valuable means of protecting cellular proteins from accidental proteolysis [2] or from possible degradation by the ATP-dependent ubiquitin system [5], or that it may directly or indirectly affect the processing or sorting of some proteins [6,7]. Moreover, acetylation may also be involved in the activity of some bioactive peptides like melanocyte stimulating hormone and adrenocorticotropic hormone [8,9].

Acylpeptide hydrolase (APH) was first purified from rat liver [10] and found to catalyze the release of the NH2-terminal amino acid from acetylated peptides, and consequently to generate shorter peptides with new free NH2-terminal residues. A few years later, the enzyme was isolated from bovine and porcine liver [11,12], rat brain [13], sheep and human erythrocytes [14–17], human placenta [18], rabbit muscle [19], and more recently from bovine lens [20] and both rat and porcine intestine [21,22]. In the rat intestine, however, the enzyme appeared to be different from APH, and has been referred to as the N-formylmethionine aminopeptidase which cleaves N-formylMet from di- and tripeptides. The amino acid sequences of the porcine, rat and human liver enzymes have been deduced from the corresponding cDNA sequences [23–25]. In these three cases, APH was found to have a Mr of 300 000 and to consist of four identical subunits containing about 730 amino acids each and having a Mr of 80 000. The porcine enzyme was identified as a serine protease containing the well known catalytic triad corresponding to Ser 587, His 707 and Asp 675 using site-directed mutagenesis [26]. Although the enzyme was found to have a relatively broad specificity toward short peptide substrates in vitro, it is not very active on proteins.

The exact biological function of APH is still unknown, since it has yet not been established whether the enzyme is involved in the degradation of Nα-acetylated proteins or in the N-terminal processing events occurring during post- or/and co-translational protein modification. It has also been suggested that the acylpeptide hydrolase may play a role in red cell maturation [15,16]. It might also act as a cell growth control factor [27]. The presence of the enzyme in the intestinal mucosa is of a great interest, since the enterocytes play an active part in protein metabolism.

In the present study, we describe an improved procedure for purifying milligram quantities of acylpeptide hydrolase to homogeneity, as well as further characterizing of the enzyme from porcine intestinal mucosa and molecular cloning of the corresponding cDNA.

N-Acetyl-l-alanine-p-nitroanilide, iodoacetamide, phenylmethane sulfonylfluoride, 1,10-phenanthroline, diisopropyl fluorophosphate and 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-carbodiimide hydrochloride as well as bovine serum albumin and protein standards for molecular mass determination were purchased from Sigma (St Louis, MO, USA) while 2-mercaptoethanol, o-phthaldialdehyde and benzamidine were from Fluka (Buchs, Switzerland). N-Acetyl-l-peptides were obtained from Bachem Fine Chemicals (Bubendorf, Switzerland). EAH Sepharose 4B, Sepharose 6B, benzamidine–Sepharose 6B, DEAE Sepharose fast flow, XK 16/20 column and molecular mass standards for sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS–PAGE) were from Pharmacia Biotech (St-Quentin en Yvelines, France). DEAE-Cellulose (Whatman 23) was supplied by Interchim (Montluçon, France). Dithiothreitol was obtained from Boehringer (Mannheim, Germany). Fluorotrans membrane (0.2 μm) was from Pall Industrie (Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France) while PM-30 and YM-100 membranes were from Amicon (Paris, France). All the other chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification.

Immediately after the pigs were slaughtered, the small intestine mucosa from four animals was scraped off with a microscope slide. The mucosa (734 g) was stirred with buffer A, 50 mM potassium phosphate containing 5 mM 2-mercaptoethanol at pH 8 (2 ml/g). The resulting suspension was further homogenized with a motor-driven Teflon-glass homogenizer and filtered through a gauze. After 1 h centrifugation at 12 000×g, proteins from the supernatant were fractionated with ammonium sulfate (20–50%). The pellet was dissolved in buffer A (670 ml), dialyzed overnight against the same buffer, and then applied to a DEAE 23 cellulose column (6×40 cm) equilibrated with buffer A. Proteins were eluted using a linear ionic strength gradient from 0 to 0.8 M KCl in buffer A. The active fractions were pooled, and the proteins concentrated using an acrylic Minitan system (Millipore), dialyzed against buffer A and finally applied to a benzamidine–Sepharose 6B column (1.5×12 cm) equilibrated with buffer A. The adsorbed proteins were eluted with a linear gradient from 0 M KCl to 0.5 M KCl in buffer A, concentrated on a YM-100 membrane and dialyzed against buffer A. The concentrated material was applied to the acetyl-l-alanine Sepharose 4B column (1×18 cm) which was washed with buffer A and eluted with a linear gradient from 0 M KCl to 0.5 M KCl. The fractions containing APH activity were pooled, concentrated using a PM-30 ultrafiltration membrane, and further applied to a Sepharose 6B column (1.5×250 cm) both equilibrated and eluted with buffer B (50 mM potassium phosphate containing 5 mM 2-mercaptoethanol and 200 mM KCl) at pH 8. The APH fractions eluted from the Sepharose 6B column were concentrated by ultrafiltration on a PM-30 membrane in order to carry out the last chromatography on DEAE Sepharose fast-flow gel equilibrated with buffer B. After a wash with buffer B, a linear KCl (0.2–0.5 M) gradient was applied in buffer A, and the resulting APH purified to homogeneity was stored at −20°C in buffer A containing 20% glycerol.

Acylpeptide hydrolase activity was routinely determined using N-acetyl-l-alanine-p-nitroanilide (AANA) [28] dissolved in dimethylsulfoxide at a concentration of 0.2 M. The reaction mixture (1 ml) containing 2 mM of the substrate in a 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 8) was preincubated at 37°C for 2 min. An appropriate amount of the enzyme solution was added and the release of p-nitroanilide was measured by recording the absorbance at 410 nm on a Kontron Uvikon 810 spectrophotometer equipped with a thermostated cuvette compartment. One unit of APH activity was defined as 1 nmol of AANA hydrolyzed per min under the conditions of the assay using ϵ410=8800 M−1 cm−1 in the case of the released p-nitroanilide.
Protein was determined using the method developed by Hartree [29] with bovine serum albumin as a standard.

SDS–PAGE under reducing conditions was carried out using Laemmli’s method [30]. Standard proteins of known molecular mass and sample of APH were heated to 100°C in the presence of 2% SDS under reducing conditions. Non-denaturing PAGE was also carried out on a 12% (w/v) polyacrylamide gel according to Gabriel [31]. Proteins were stained with Coomassie blue.

The molecular mass of the native protein was estimated by comparing its elution volume to those of molecular mass markers through the same Sepharose 6B column (1.5×250 cm), which was eluted with buffer A containing 0.35 M NaCl.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Amino acid analysis and protein sequence determination
ce:section.ce:para: The amino acid composition of the homogeneous enzyme was determined using a Beckman 6300 amino acid analyzer after 24, 48 and 72 h hydrolysis of the protein (1–2 nmol) at 110°C in 6 N HCl containing 0.1% phenol.

For sequence determination, the protein was reduced and carboxymethylated prior to Edman degradation, which was carried out with 200–300 pmol of protein on an Applied Biosystems 470A protein sequencer [32], and phenylthiohydantoin identification was performed by means of a phenylthiohydantoin column (2.1×220 mm, particle size 5 μm), also from Applied Biosystems. Two different preparations of the purified enzyme (4–5 nmol) were used for this purpose.

The enzyme was incubated at 37°C with the reagents indicated below for 5 min (n=3). The remaining enzyme activity was determined using the standard assay procedure upon adding the substrate directly to the incubation mixture.

The following molar solutions were used: DEPC in absolute ethanol, benzamidine, IAA, DTT and 2-mercaptoethanol in 50 mM potassium phosphate (pH 8) and 1,10-phenanthroline in dimethyl sulfoxide, while PMSF and DFP were diluted with dry isopropanol to 0.17 M and 0.4 M, respectively.

The Km and Vmax values of the enzyme-catalyzed hydrolysis of the synthetic peptide substrates were determined with Ki values obtained using Dixon’s procedure [33], and all the experiments were carried out in triplicate. The enzyme was incubated with the peptide substrates Ac-(Ala)2, Ac-(Ala)3 and Ac-(Ala)4 at 37°C in a 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 8) in a total volume of 1 ml. The reaction was stopped by adding 12 N HCl (30 μl). Three incubation times (from 1 to 10 min) were used at each peptide concentration. 10 N NaOH (20 μl) was added to an aliquot (500 μl) of the reaction mixture and the amount of released free α-NH2 was determined using the o-phthaldialdehyde method [34]. As a control, the enzyme was incubated without the substrate. The reaction products were analyzed by performing reversed-phase high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) on a Lichrosorb RP 18 column (8×250 mm, particle size 7 μm; Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). Elution was carried out with a linear gradient (5–30%) of acetonitrile in 0.1% H3PO4 for 20 min and was monitored at 214 nm.
The Ki values were determined with Ac-l-Ala and Ac-d-Ala using AANA as the substrate, with the same procedure as that described above in the case of the enzyme assay.

ce:section.ce:section-title: RNA isolation and construction of a porcine intestinal cDNA library
ce:section.ce:para: Total RNA was isolated from the intestine of an 8-week-old pig according to the Qiagen RNAesy maxi kit method. A cDNA library was constructed using the Marathon cDNA amplification kit (Clontech). A 2-μg sample of total RNA was converted into cDNA with oligo-dT as primer and ligated at both ends with a special adapter containing the two primers AP1 and AP2 according to the instructions of the manufacturer. The Marathon cDNA library from intestine was used as a template for the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

The sense S1 (5′-CCTGGCAATGTGGGCCACCAG-3′) and S2 (5′-GTGTCCCCTGGACAGGCATTC-3′) gene-specific primers were designed based on the nucleotide sequence of porcine liver APH cDNA clone [23] and corresponded to residues 552–558 and 244–250 of the amino acid sequence, respectively. AS1 and AS2 were the antisense primers of the S1 and S2 primers, respectively.

In order to identify the cDNA sequence of the APH gene, three PCRs were performed using a 1:25 dilution of the cDNA library in sterilized water, as template. The first PCR used the S2 and AS1 gene-specific primers under the following conditions: 94°C for 30 s, 68°C for 30 s and 72°C for 2 min (5 cycles), and 94°C for 30 s, 66°C for 30 s and 72°C for 2 min (25 cycles), with a final extension at 72°C for 7 min.

The 3′-RACE and 5′-RACE PCR procedures were carried out with the anchor primer AP1 provided in the kit, combined with the gene-specific primer S2 and AS2 for the 3′-RACE end and 5′-RACE end, respectively. The following temperature program was used: 94°C for 30 s, 64°C for 30 s, and 72°C for 2 min (35 cycles), with a final extension at 72°C for 7 min. Additional steps were performed with an aliquot of the initial 3′-RACE and 5′-RACE PCR samples as template and the use of nested primer AP2 provided in the kit, and the gene-specific primers S1 and AS2 for the 3′-RACE end and 5′-RACE end, respectively. Thirty-five cycles of PCR were performed, each cycle being as follows: 94°C for 30 s, 64°C for 30 s, and 72°C for 2 min, with a final extension at 72°C for 7 min.
The PCR fragments were purified using the QIAEX II DNA purification kit (Promega) as described by the manufacturer, and inserted into the pCR 2.1 Topo vector with TA cloning kit (Invitrogen).

The recombinant pCR2.1 Topo vector was used to transform Top 10F′ one-shot competent cell (Invitrogen). The cDNA clones from recombinant colonies were isolated using a DNA purification system (Qiagen), and identified by restriction mapping, size determination and sequencing.
DNA sequencing was performed on both DNA strands by the dideoxynucleotide chain-termination method using an automated DNA sequencer (Eurogentec, Brussels, Belgium).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Purification and molecular properties of acylpeptide hydrolase
ce:section.ce:para: APH was purified to apparent homogeneity as described in Section 2. Table 1 shows that the seven-step purification of intestinal mucosa resulted in a 5500-fold purification of the enzyme, the specific activity of which was as high as 105 000 units per mg of protein, giving an overall yield of about 9%. The enzyme could be safely stored at −20°C in buffer A containing 20% glycerol.

As can be seen from Table 2, the amino acid composition of the enzyme purified from intestinal mucosa was very similar to that deduced from the cDNA nucleotide sequence of both the rat [23] and pig liver [24] enzymes, except for Trp, Pro and Met. The total number of amino acids in the pig intestinal APH turned out however to be substantially smaller than in the rat and pig liver enzymes (689 versus 732). No phenylthiohydantoin-amino acid was detected using the automatic Edman degradation procedure. This strongly suggests that the NH2-terminal amino acid of the protein was probably blocked.

The homogeneity of APH was examined by performing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis under both nondenaturing and denaturing conditions. In the absence of SDS (Fig. 1A), a single Coomassie blue-stained band was observed. As shown in Fig. 1B, the relative molecular mass of the purified protein as determined by SDS–PAGE was 75±2 kDa, while the native enzyme had a molecular mass of 280 kDa, as determined by gel filtration (data not shown). All in all, these data strongly suggested that pig intestinal APH is probably composed of four identical subunits. The possible presence of any carbohydrate in the purified enzyme could definitely be ruled out, since both the Schiff reaction performed on the protein after SDS–PAGE and the free sugar determination after gentle acid hydrolysis of the protein were negative (data not shown).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effects of pH on enzyme activity
ce:section.ce:para: The pH dependence of the pig intestinal APH activity was measured at 37°C and at pH values ranging from 5 to 9.5, using 50 mM of potassium phosphate, glycine and Tris–HCl buffers (data not shown). The optimal pH value was 8 in the case of the potassium phosphate and Tris–HCl buffers, and 9 in that of the glycine buffer. It is worth mentioning here that the enzyme activity occurring in potassium phosphate and glycine buffers at pH 7 was only one-third of that recorded in the Tris–HCl buffer. This difference, however, appeared not to be due to the Tris cation itself but rather to the chloride anion, since both NaCl and KCl at a 100 mM concentration were found to induce a twofold increase in the enzyme activity, at all the ionic strengths tested (data not shown).

The kinetic parameters of pig intestinal APH-catalyzed hydrolysis of a variety of acetylated alanyl substrates are listed in Table 3. The Km values of all the acetylated l-alanine peptides from the dipeptide to the tetrapeptide varied very little (0.7±0.1 mM), unlike the Vmax, which was found to decrease as a function of the peptide length (about 200 to 50 nmol/min per μg enzyme). In all the experiments, the reaction products, which were identified by HPLC, consisted on the one hand of Ac-Ala, and on the other hand of Ala, (Ala)2 and (Ala)3, depending on the initial peptide substrate. Both Ac-(Ala)2 and Ac-(Ala)3 were found to be better substrates than the usual APH synthetic substrate (AANA), since their Vmax/Km values were significantly higher.

APH was able to catalyze the hydrolysis of neither Ac-d-Ala nor Ac-l-Ala, the latter of which was a more potent inhibitor than the former (Ki=0.4 and 17.0 mM, respectively). We therefore used Ac-l-Ala in the present study as the ligand for the affinity chromatography. Using Cornish Bowden’s method [33], we observed a mixed inhibition with the d-amino acid and a competitive inhibition with the l-amino acid.

Several protease inhibitors were tested in order to investigate which amino acid residues in the enzyme might play a catalytic role (Table 4). The enzyme was completely inactivated by 0.1 mM DFP, whereas the inhibition was as low as 12.5% with 1 mM PMSF, probably because the latter is less soluble in aqueous buffers than the former. Benzamidine, the synthetic inhibitor of trypsin-like serine proteases, which was used as a ligand for the affinity chromatography during the purification of pig intestinal APH, was actually devoid of any inhibitory effects up to a concentration of 100 mM. It was therefore concluded that APH possesses an interaction site for benzamidine, which was obviously not located at its catalytic site. DEPC, a histidine modifying reagent, inhibited APH at a concentration as low as 1 mM. Sulfhydryl-reducing agents such as 2-mercaptoethanol and DTT at quite a high concentration (10 mM) did not affect the specific enzyme activity. A possible stabilizing effect was even observed in the presence of 1 mM 2-mercaptoethanol. Since the sulfhydryl-modifying reagent (IAA) partly inhibited APH at 10 mM, cysteine residues might be involved in the stabilization of the enzyme, probably via disulfide bonds.
Chelating agents such as EDTA and 1,10-phenanthroline did not affect the enzyme activity, and surprisingly enough, a 20% activation of the enzyme occurred with 1 mM EDTA.

Porcine intestine APH was cloned by PCR using internal primers based on the sequence of porcine liver APH [23]. The sequence reported in Fig. 2 resulted from alignment of the three overlapping PCR fragments. This sequence contained 2377 bp with an open reading frame for a protein of 731 amino acid residues, and a 184-bp 3′-untranslated region with a putative polyadenylation signal (AATAAA) followed by a short poly(A) tail.

When the amino acid sequence deduced from the nucleotide sequence of the gene amplification product was compared with that of liver APH, the first amino acid in the former sequence corresponds to the second amino acid in the latter. However, since the Met initiator was not found, it is strongly suggested that the cDNA-deduced amino acid sequence from porcine intestine lacked the N-terminal amino acid.

The cDNA nucleotide sequence from the porcine intestinal library contained a single substitution compared with that of the cDNA isolated from a porcine liver library [23]. This difference which is located at nucleotide 314 on the liver sequence altered the corresponding amino acid sequence, since Val 105 is substituted for Ala.
The C-terminal residue of the polypeptide chain derived from the cDNA cloning and sequence analysis (Ser 731) was confirmed using carboxypeptidase Y analysis (data not shown).

In this study, we describe an improved procedure for purifying from porcine intestinal mucosa the N-acylpeptide hydrolase which releases the N-acetylamino acid from acetylated peptides. The molecular mass of this tetrameric enzyme was estimated to be 280 kDa,which is quite similar to the values reported elsewhere on material from other sources, including rat and human tissues [11,15,20,35]. The purified APH was apparently not glycosylated, and its specific activity on the usual synthetic substrate AANA was fourfold to sixfold higher than those measured with the rat liver enzyme [35] as well as with both the human placenta and erythrocyte enzymes [15,18]. When the porcine intestinal enzyme, which was purified in the present study, was compared with both the rat and pig liver enzymes [23,24], the former APH was found to exhibit the same structural properties, i.e., the same subunit composition and N-terminal blocked residue.

Although the enzyme has been found to be catalytically efficient on a variety of acetylated peptides, acetylalanyl peptides have been described as being the best substrates. Some discrepancies exist among the results published so far on the enzyme’s affinity and its rate of hydrolysis as a function of the peptide chain lengths. In the present study, the Vmax values obtained with pig intestinal APH decreased from 201 to 52 nmol/min per μg enzyme as the number of alanyl residues increased from two to four, as compared with 107 to 269 nmol/min per μg enzyme in the case of the rat liver enzyme [35]. Our results are consistent with the existence of some steric hindrance of the active site, whereas the acylpeptide hydrolase from other sources has been found to exhibit the highest rate of hydrolysis with Ac-Ala tripeptide [11,15,35–37]. The Km values we recorded with the acetylated alanyl peptides are comparable however to those obtained previously on both the rat liver [24] and human erythrocyte [36] enzymes. APH did not cleave Ac-l-Ala or Ac-d-Ala. These acetylated amino acids were nevertheless able to tightly bind to the enzyme and act as strong inhibitors, especially Ac-l-Ala. The enzyme was found to exhibit a competitive inhibition toward the l-amino acid, as in the rat liver [24], and the calculated Ki values were similar in both cases (0.4 and 1.5 mM). Ac-l-Ala has also been reported to competitively inhibit the human erythrocyte enzyme [38].

With the active site reagents such as DFP or DEPC, our results were in line with those published by Kobayashi and Smith [24] on rat liver APH. One or several cysteinyl residues were found to be probably necessary to stabilize the active enzyme conformation, as suggested by the data obtained in the inhibition experiments with sulfhydryl-modifying agents. Scaloni et al. [39] have shown that APH contains three disulfide bridges per monomer and suggested that Cys-30 and/or Cys-64, which are located near the active site, might be involved in stability of catalytic site. It has been recently shown [25] that the amino acid sequence around the active site of the acylpeptide hydrolase of human erythrocytes is identical to the consensus sequence found to exist in mammalian serine proteases and esterases, namely Gly-X-Ser-X-Gly. The latter authors suggested that the active site of the APH may be similar to a member of the prolyl endopeptidase family which was recently described in porcine brain [40]. Our results are in good agreement with the fact that intestinal acylpeptide hydrolase is a serine protease involving serine and histidine at its active site.

The 2377-nucleotide long cDNA isolated in this study encoded a 731-amino-acid protein. Except for a single nucleotide difference, the cDNA sequence coding for the intestinal APH was identical to that reported by Mitta et al. [23] for the liver enzyme. This difference could be due to an allelic variation or to some PCR artifact. Whatever the case, the results from sequence analysis definitely show that the same gene is coding for both porcine liver and intestinal APH.

The exact physiological role of this enzyme in the intestine still remains to be elucidated. It might be involved in the intracellular protein turnover [11,35]. The results of the present study also suggest that APH might be involved in the final steps of digestion of the N-acetylated peptides released by the combined action of endo- and exopeptidases in the intestinal lumen which are able to pass through the enterocyte apical membrane [41]. The acetylated amino acid which is released by APH may furthermore be hydrolyzed by an acylase, giving acetate and a free amino acid which may then be utilized for protein synthesis. The existence of acylase has already been described in several tissues, and especially in the porcine intestine [42]. Moreover, very low levels of both APH and acylase I, and even no enzyme activity at all, have been observed in small cell lung cancer [27]. This observation suggests that the inactivation of these enzymes could lead to some accumulation of N-terminally acylated growth factors which are normally involved in the cell physiology. Both substrate specificity and cellular localization studies are under way with a view to specifying the potential role of this enzyme in the intestinal mucosa.
